text.p: These are the leading stories in the Sarajevo press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Three options for dividing disputed northern Bosnian town of Brcko exist, although the ultimate resolution of the town's fate might be international protectorate, Bosnian Croat news agency Habena quotes local official Mijo Anic as saying.

- Representatives of World Bank warn Bosnian delegation that without making arrangment with International Monetary Fund (IMF) and forming Central Bank of Bosnia as part of that arrangement, donors won't hold their next conference planned for March.
- Moslem-Croat Federation Prime Minister Edhem Bicakcic and U.S. officials discuss creating conditions for boosting privatisation process in Bosnia.
- Croatian government has no word that Serbs from the Croatian enclave of eastern Slavonia want to move to the disputed Bosnian town of Brcko, Croatian deputy Prime Minister Ivica Kostovic says.
- Meeting of joint American-Bosnian Business Council was held in New York city on Tuesday. Reconstruction, privatisation, trade and investment issues were discussed.

- Croatian state television (HRT) denies interfering with frequency of Bosnian state television and all repeaters that HRT uses in Bosnia are legal with permission from Bosnian officials, HRT official says in an interview.
- Three abandoned Moslem houses near the Croat-ontrolled southern Bosnian town of Capljina destroyed by six explosions.

- Dario Kordic, former Bosnian Croat militia commander and indicted war criminal, lives in Croat-controlled west Herzegovina in southern Bosnia together with several other Croat indictees, newspaper quotes its sources as saying.
- Draft of law banning smoking in public places is expected to be announced in Moslem-Croat Federation soon.
- World Bank has in 1996 made 1,257 contracts with companies doing reconstruction jobs in Bosnia on th basis of its loans of $216.6 million.
- Battle simulation centre opened in village of Zunovnica, near Sarajevo, as a part of U.S.-sponsored "Train and Equip" millitary aid programme.

- In areas where Bosnian Serbs or Croats form a majority, Moslems do not enjoy religious freedom, top Islamic leader in Bosnia Reisu-l-ulema Mustafa Ceric says in interview. --Sarajevo newsroom, +387-71-663-864
